transcript.sentence: Welcome to Abbott's fourth quarter 2022 earnings conference call.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: During the question and answer session, you will be able to ask your question by pressing the star 1 1 keys on your touch tone phone.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I would now like to introduce Mr. Scott Leinenweber, Vice President, Investor Relations, Licensing, and Acquisitions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Good morning, and thank you for joining us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: With me today are Robert Ford, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and Bob Funk, Executive Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Kurt and Bob will provide opening remarks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Following their comments, we'll take your questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Before we get started, some statements made today may be forward-looking for purposes of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, including the expected financial results for 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Abbott cautions that these forward-looking statements are subject to risk and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated in the forward-looking statements.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Economic, competitive, governmental, technological, and other factors that may affect AVID's operations are discussed in Item 1A, Risk Factors, to our annual report on Form 10-K for the year-ended December 31, 2021.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: AVID undertakes no obligation to release publicly any revisions to forward-looking statements as a result of subsequent events or developments, except as required by law.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: On today's conference call, as in the past, non-GAAP financial measures will be used to help investors understand Abbott's ongoing business performance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: These non-GAAP financial measures are reconciled with the comparable GAAP financial measures in our earnings news release and regulatory filings from today, which are available on our website at abbott.com.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Note that Abbott has not provided the GAAP financial measure for organic sales growth, excluding COVID testing sales, on a forward-looking basis, because the company is unable to predict future changes in foreign exchange rates, which could impact reported sales growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Unless otherwise noted, our commentary on sales growth refers to organic sales growth, which excludes the impact of foreign exchange.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: With that, I will now turn the call over to Robert.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Scott.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: Good morning, everyone.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04

transcript.sentence: And thank you for joining us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Today, I'll discuss our 2022 results, as well as our outlook for this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: For the full year 2022, we achieved ongoing earnings per share of $5.34, which is well above the original EPS guidance we set at the beginning of the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As you know, macro business conditions have been highly dynamic and challenging over the last few years, particularly for US-based multinational companies. COVID-19 pandemic played a big role in this, of course.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We saw the US dollar strengthen significantly and inflation reached new heights last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Supply chains continue to face challenges and our healthcare customers have been navigating staffing challenges that are are negatively impacting certain medical device procedure trends and routine diagnostic testing volumes.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As we start the new year, however, while these factors remain headwinds, I'm cautiously optimistic that we're starting to see them peak and, in some cases, ease a bit.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Over the past few months, the impact of COVID-19 on society has lessened, and economies around the world are increasingly reopening.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In the U.S., the U.S. dollar weakened a bit, and inflation has eased somewhat.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And hospital-based procedures and routine testing trends continue to steadily improve in many areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As you know, COVID testing has been a big part of our story these past couple of years, and I'm proud of what our team has built. a full suite of tests across several platforms, and the intentionality and how we established a leading role in the world's response to the pandemic.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In total, we've delivered nearly 3 billion COVID tests globally since the start of the pandemic.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Going forward, we expect COVID-19 to transition to more of an endemic, seasonal type of respiratory virus.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And with that, COVID testing, while still important, is expected to decline significantly.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We expect variants will continue to emerge, and therefore our tests will remain an important part of our leading respiratory testing portfolio, along with flu, RSV, and strep, which we offer across multiple testing platforms, including lab-based systems in hospitals, small desktop devices in urgent care centers and physician offices, as well as at-home tests.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As we reflect back on the impact of COVID testing efforts over the last few years, it's clear that our success in this area will have a positive, long-lasting impact for the company.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It strengthened our strategic position in diagnostics through the expansion of our installed base of instruments, including IDNOW, our rapid point-of-care molecular testing platform, and through the opening of new testing channels, such as physician offices and at-home testing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It enabled us to increase investments in priority growth areas across the company, including R&D and commercial initiatives, in support of several recent and upcoming new product launches, while at the same time increasing returns to our shareholders in the forms of dividend growth share repurchasing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And lastly, it further strengthened our overall financial health and balance sheet which will provide significant strategic flexibility as we look to build and grow the company even further.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'm proud of the role we played in fighting COVID the last few years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It reinforced our purpose, had a meaningful impact on society, and enhanced our long-term strategic position going forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Turning now to our outlook for 2023, as we announced this morning, we forecast ongoing earnings per share of $4.30 to $4.50.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We forecast organic sales growth, excluding COVID testing sales, in the high single digits, and we forecast around $2 billion of of COVID testing sales for the full year 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I'll provide more details on our results by business area before turning the call over to Bob. I'll start with nutrition, where sales declined around 6% in both the fourth quarter and full year as a result of manufacturing disruptions at one of our U.S. infant formula facilities last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Production at the facility is up and running.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And as we've mentioned previously, our initial supply priority was to the WIC, Women, Infants and Children Federal Food Assistance Program, to ensure underserved participants have access to infant formula.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As our manufacturing capacity has continued to recover, we've been able to increase production of our non-WIC brands, with a focus on serving the broader infant formula market and building back inventory levels on retail shelves.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Turning to diagnostics, where, as expected, sales growth in the fourth quarter was negatively impacted by year-over-year decline in COVID-19 test sales.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: COVID testing sales were $1.1 billion in the fourth quarter, with rapid testing platforms including BinaxNOW in the U.S., PanBio internationally, and IDNOW globally compromising approximately 95% of these sales.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: COVID testing sales, worldwide diagnostics grew over 11 percent in the fourth quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Growth in the quarter was led by rapid diagnostics where, excluded COVID-19 tests, sales increased 30 percent compared to the prior year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As I mentioned earlier, during the pandemic we significantly expanded the installed base of IDNOW and opened new testing channels.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: This expanded footprint drove strong growth and supported testing needs when flu and other respiratory infection surged late last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: During this past year, we continued the rollout of Alinity, our innovative suite of diagnostic instruments and expand test menus across our platforms for immunoassay, clonal chemistry and molecular testing. to establish pharmaceuticals, or EPD, where sales increased 8% in the fourth quarter and over 10% for the full year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: EPD continues to perform at a high level, having carved out an attractive growth space in the global pharmaceutical market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Specifically, our geographic focus on fast-growing emerging markets with a broad portfolio targeting attractive therapeutic areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Strong performance in the quarter was led by double digit growth across several geographies including India, China, Brazil, and Mexico.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I'll wrap up with medical devices, where sales grew 7.5% in the fourth quarter and 8% for the full year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Growth in both the quarter and full year was led by double digit growth in electrophysiology, structural heart and diabetes care in the U.S. Internationally, sales growth was negatively impacted by COVID surges in China during the fourth quarter, as well as lingering supply challenges in a couple areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In diabetes care, fourth quarter sales of Freestyle Libre, our market-leading continuous glucose monitoring system, grew over 40 percent in the U.S., and global Libre sales reached $4.3 billion for full year 2022.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We continue to strengthen our medical device portfolio with numerous pipeline advancements and launches, including recent U.S. regulatory approvals of Avair, our highly innovative leadless pacemaker used to treating people with slow heart rhythms.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Eterna, the smallest implantable rechargeable spinal cord stimulation system currently available in the in the market for the treatment of chronic pain.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Freestyle Libre 3, which provides continuous glucose readings in the world's smallest and most accurate wearable sensor.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Libre was recently named the best medical technology of the last 50 years by Galen Foundation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And finally Navitor, our latest generation transcatheter aortic heart valve replacement system.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, in summary, 2022 was another highly successful year for Abbott.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We're optimistic about the early signs we're seeing of an improving operating environment and excited about the growth opportunities that lie ahead for all of our businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we continue to strengthen our overall strategic position with a steady cadence of innovative technologies that are either in the early stages of launching or expected to launch over the course of this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'll now turn over the call to Bob.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thanks, Robert.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As Scott mentioned earlier, please note that all references to sales growth rates, unless otherwise noted, are on an organic basis, which excludes the impact of foreign exchange.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Turning to our results, sales decreased 6.1% on an organic basis in the quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: COVID testing-related sales were $1.1 billion in the quarter, which, while stronger than the forecast we provided back in October, reflect a year-over-year decline versus sales in the fourth quarter of the prior year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Excluding both COVID testing-related sales and U.S. infant formula sales that were impacted by manufacturing disruptions last year in our nutrition business, total AVID sales increased 7.1% on our organic basis in the fourth quarter, and 7.4% for the full year 2022.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Foreign exchange had an unfavorable year-over-year impact of 5.9% on fourth quarter sales, which resulted in a somewhat favorable impact on sales compared to exchange rates at the time of our earnings call in October, as we saw the dollar weaken a bit late last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Regarding other aspects of the P&L for the quarter, the adjusted gross margin ratio was 55.6 percent of sales, which reflects the impact of the nutrition manufacturing disruptions and inflation we've experienced on certain manufacturing and distribution costs across our businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: R&D investment was 6.5% of sales, and adjusted SG&A expense was 28% of sales in the fourth quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Turning to our outlook for the full year 2023, today we issued guidance for full year ongoing earnings per share of $4.30 to $4.50.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Over the year, we forecast organic sales growth, excluding the impact of COVID testing-related sales, to be in the high single digits.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: We forecast COVID testing-related sales of around $2 billion, with around $750 million forecasted in the first quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Based on current rates, we would expect exchange to have an unfavorable impact of approximately 1 percent on our reported full year sales, which includes an expected unfavorable impact of approximately 3 percent on our first quarter reported sales.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: We forecast an adjusted gross margin ratio for the full year of approximately 56 percent of sales.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Also, for the year, we forecast R&D investment of around $2.5 billion and SG&A investment of around $11 billion, which reflects investments to support several ongoing and upcoming new product launches and strategic growth initiatives.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: We forecast net interest expense of around $300 million, non-operating income of around $450 million dollars and a full year adjusted tax rate of approximately 14% for the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: As Robert mentioned, the strength and resiliency of our business, particularly since the start of the pandemic, has allowed us to concurrently invest in our strategic priorities, provide strong return to our shareholders, and further strengthen our financial health, which provides provides a strong base on which to grow the company going forward.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: With that, we'll now open the call for questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: At this time, we will conduct the question and answer session.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: You will then hear an automated message advising you that your hand is raised.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: To withdraw your question, please press star 1-1 again. quality, we kindly ask that you please use your handset instead of your speakerphone when asking your question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Again, that's star 1 1 to ask a question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Please stand by while we compile the Q&A roster.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And our first question will come from Robbie Marcus from J.P. Morgan.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I mean, there's obviously a macro environment here that's been complex, and you've mentioned it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: So I think that we've factored some of that improvement and some of that stabilization in there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: I mean, I don't necessarily I don't think that we've got too many moving parts here.

transcript.sentence: I mean, obviously, we run a, the company's got a lot of different business and business segments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But I mean, if you look at really the two areas, I would say, Robbie, that kind of have had this effect of maybe sometimes distorting the results a little bit is our COVID testing business and the impact of the recall products last year, right?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, you know, from a COVID perspective in 2022, we actually sold more tests than we sold in 2021.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So if you take those out of the equation, you kind of go back to what we were growing pre-pandemic, right, which was, you know, top tier, you know, high single digits, seven to 8% growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: That's what we grew in 2022, again, excluding COVID and the impact of the recall products.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then if you take that comp out on the recall product side, this year as we return to market and look at the base business, obviously without the COVID testing, we're gonna be growing high single digits, probably at a higher end of that pre-pandemic range, probably eight plus percent.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think it starts with the top line and that's probably the number one part of our guidance is obviously making sure that we feel that our top line is taking advantage of all the good parts, all the good product launches, et cetera, that we have.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And from that perspective, I think a lot of what we're doing kind of supports that ongoing high single-digit growth rate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: If you look at our device portfolio, we'll be looking at high single-digit growth rate, low double-digit growth rate, combination of both kind of recovery the study recovery procedures that that we're seeing uh... combined with all these product launches that that we've got lined up now that will also we have a full year impact with a delivery three amulet of their navigator cardiamens you know eternal on on the on the neuromodulation side uh... our mapping system uh... any p we're gonna launch a new ablation catheter so So the device portfolio is well set up to be able to drive those high single, high single, sorry, high single digit, low double digit growth rate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I mean, I think we're gonna continue to see strong performance in EPD.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think as the world continues to reopen, those emerging markets continue to be a great opportunity for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We've strengthened our position in diagnostics throughout these years, and we'll see continued successful rollout of Alinity in our core and molecular diagnostics and then the recovery and in from Formula 2.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think you put all that in place.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Our core business, Abbott, that we knew pre-pandemic is actually stronger than we were pre-pandemic with the investments that we made.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think that's the other part of, I guess, in the P&L, if you look at what we've been able to do this year is because of COVID and the investments that we made during COVID in these growth areas, we're able to drive this high single digit growth across the company with a fairly flat investment line, whether it's R&D and SG&A, so really getting the leverage across the businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, I mean, I think it really starts with our top line and the confidence we have and the products we're launching, the pipeline, the positions we have.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then COVID, we forecast about 2 billion next year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think that's the right number right now.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I'd say those are some of the moving pieces there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But fundamentally, we're in a real strong position in terms of our long-term growth opportunities, leading positions in these attractive growth areas, strong pipeline, which I'm sure we'll get into some of them, and a strong balance sheet.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that's how this has been constructed, and I think that we're in a good position here.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_08

transcript.sentence: Secondly, we are seeing a steady improvement in procedure trends in the U.S. and Europe.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: We've been seeing that and we expect to continue to see kind of a steady improvement there on procedure trends over the course of the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: In our nutrition business, we will see improvement as we continue to supply the market, in particular the non-WIC segment of the infant formula market in the U.S., and so we'll recover share there, so we'll have the impact of that over the course of the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: For China, Robbie, I'd say, you know, we've assumed a softer start in Q1, given some of the dynamics there at the start of this year, but we anticipate that will improve over the course of the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And so all those changes, all those impacts on the top line that builds over the course of the year will flow through to earnings, as Robert talked about, we're going to get leverage in the middle here.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And so, you know, for the first quarter, we're, you know, we think, you know, earnings will be approximately a dollar, and then we'll build from there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: On your question on foreign exchange, you know, rates have improved a bit recently, but exchange is still a headwind, particularly on earnings.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: You know, current rates, as I said in my opening remarks, exchange is approximately 1 percent headwind on sales.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: EPS, you know, it's a little bit more than 30 cent headwind for us in 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: The fall through impact when currencies move like we have seen over the last year is always complex.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Translation is just a piece of the impact, and while that has improved from where we were a few months ago, it still remains a headwind.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: One of the biggest drivers that we're seeing is the impact from our hedging program.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: We realized pretty significant hedging gains last year that won't repeat this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: You can really see the impact of those hedging gains on our 2022 results.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Last year, there was a pretty significant exchange headwind on sales, you know, a little over 5% or $2.1 billion, but a fairly modest impact on earnings, it was less than a dime.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And that was really the benefit we realized last year on those hedging gains that won't repeat in 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: You know, that's not a unique dynamic that we're seeing, we're seeing that from some other multinationals as well.

transcript.sentence: So kind of Libre One was that, you know, we had a significant improvement in that situation in NQ4.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I expect, you know, one or two more months of, you know, until we can completely resolve that, but a significant improvement over there on our international performance.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think one of the key things on the international side is, you know, it was a little bit of this supply chain on chips that we had, like that I said, is mostly behind us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The other part of it is, you know, the upgrade cycle, right?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And when you go with an accelerated upgrade cycle versus, you know, with Libre 3 that we did from Libre 2 in some of our key markets, And when we went from Libre 1 to Libre 2, we let that upgrade kind of somewhat happen naturally.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And that takes about a year and a half, two years to actually complete.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: For Libre 3, we wanted to go more aggressively in some of these markets.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that takes your sales force away from new demand generation to making sure that we can get the scripts and do all the behind-the-scenes work for those upgrades.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that's, I would say, that's still ongoing, but I'd call it about 80 to 85% complete.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So then that allows us, starting now in 2023 on the international side, to start kind of driving new additions here.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I'd say I expect a continued growth in the U.S. in terms of market expansion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Basel opportunity, I think, is a great opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: and I think it'll start in the US, but I think we're seeing that also internationally.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And now that we've got this supply chain issue largely behind us, and the upgrade cycle, again, largely behind us, we can focus our demand generation activities on new users.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think that that's one key driver of growth for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Can we see a path for another 20% growth in 2023?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Yeah, I can.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think there's a lot of opportunities of growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think one of them that you mentioned being the basal expansion is a significant opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think we've been leading the charge over here, Larry, in terms of generating the clinical data that's required to be able to support reimbursement.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It'll start, I think, in the U.S., but I don't think it'll be a U.S.-only phenomenon.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But in the U.S., it'll probably start first.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You've got about four million type 2 basal patients
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In the US, about a third of them are Medicare.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And even if you assume a reasonable market penetration, you also have to assume a difference in annual utilization rates versus a type 1, an MDI, or a pumper.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But even if you take all that in consideration, the opportunity starts with a 1 billion, and it can range depending on the speed and the uptake of that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think this is a great growth opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And like I said, I don't think it's a U.S. only situation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think this is gonna start to expand across the world given the clinical data that you see with Libre and the impact that it has.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think this is another great opportunity for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, the vitamin C issue that you asked, you know, we've submitted our response.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, we're working with the FDA on this.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I'm not gonna try and forecast that approval, but what I will say is that as soon as that gets approved, then we'll start to see the product with a couple quarters connect to IED pump systems.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We have already launched a connected IED system, AID system in Europe.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Initial results of the receptivity of that product, of that combined product in Europe is being very favorable.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think that's another key growth driver for us in 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then finally, I would say on the pipeline perspective, I don't think it's a 2023 milestone for sales, but I think it's an important development activity for us, is gonna be running our trial for the combined glucose ketone sensor with the FDA and generating the data to support a dual sensor.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Because I think, again, as I've mentioned, it seems to be the go-to sensor for pumpers will be this ability to measure glucose and ketones and factoring that into the algorithms.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that's gonna be, that's obviously having a lot of focus of us in terms of running that trial.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then finally, I would say outside of Libre, the Lingo platform is another kind of key growth driver for us, you know, I've talked about, you know, expanding Libre, the Libre platform outside of diabetes and using this more broadly for a much more broader target.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, we have a separate team that's been working on that development.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Larry, we will be launching two Lingo products this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In Europe, I'd say the first one will probably be in the first half of this year and the second one in the second half.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I've talked about Libre being a $10 billion product by 2028, that implies a 15% annual growth rate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We'll do better than that this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think the opportunities we have to be able to drive to that kind of revenue for this product are very real.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think we've been executing very strongly on all these areas.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: That's super helpful, just one brief follow up. you talked about uh... me being excited about uh... triclip opportunity uh... jp morgan uh... because it's just it's mud uh... i know you know that it's limited what you can say you know because representing the trial in a data uh... it a cc but how are you thinking about that opportunity relative to my troll you know i i i do you still andy still expect to uh... you know about the still expect approval in the u s by year-end twenty-three thanks for taking the questions uh... i think the great opportunity for us and you know i think that we've shown that we're we're definitely here one of the leaders uh... when it comes to uh... you know could be part of part of our repair market uh... and uh... you know do i think it's uh... do i think it is uh... it could be bigger than michael i i'm not sure i would go that far yet but i i would say that the uptake of trial of the tri cusp in repair market i think will be faster than the uptake for the Mitral just because I think when Mitral was launched, it was the first repair system, and now you have a large group of implanting positions that are familiar with the CLIP technology, are familiar with mapping that CLIP technology in the procedure.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We did make some changes to the delivery device for the CLIP.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's a little different anatomy, a little bit more challenging to get there with the CLIP in the tricuspid area, but I think that it's a great opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I mean, I think there's three million people today that suffer from tricuspid regurgitation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: There's not a lot of really good options available for treatment, which is why we invested in the trial here in the U.S. to bring products to the trial.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Like you said, we're gonna be presenting that in a couple of months.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think it's a great opportunity for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We've already seen real nice traction of that in Europe.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, we launched that in 2021.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, the team wanted to launch it right in COVID, and I must say at the beginning, I was somewhat against that, but they proved me wrong, and the product's done really well in Europe.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think this is another great opportunity for us here in the U.S. too.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So we're not ignoring MitraClip.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: It's part of our entire portfolio, and I think the combination of those two products in the implanting position will be very powerful for Abbott.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: All right, thanks so much.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: One moment for our next question, please.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And our next question will come from Josh Jennings from Cowen.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Your line is open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Hi, thanks for taking the questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Good morning.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Robert, I was hoping just to follow up on Larry's questions just on Libra, but just thinking more kind of in the out years and this $10 billion target that you've set.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: I think maybe just I think you outlined everything for 2023 probably holds true for you know over the next five years but just if you could reiterate your confidence we're not in that 10 billion dollar out year target and just do you expect consolidation between pump and cgm companies and maybe it'd be just great to hear strategic rationale of whether a combined pump CGM offering under one roof would be advantageous for either Abbott or another company.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And then the second question is just on the Abbott tour and the launch here in the United States.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: What would represent a win for Abbott from a U.S. share game perspective?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And what segment is a low-hanging fruit considering the current label?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Is it the elderly patients that don't have a long life expectancy that are high risk or even intermediate risk?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: And how do you expect an Avatar launch to play out and add to the medical device growth in 2023.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Thanks for taking the questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_05

transcript.sentence: Sure.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Well, I mean, I guess on Libre, you know, to your question on, you know, how to get to 10 billion by 2028, I mean, you know, the math will say 15%, right?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: How do you get to that 15%?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I mean, there are real three key areas, and I talked a little bit about them, but, you I'd say, first of all, it's to continue to have a dominant share in the heavy insulin user segment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We have that today with the non-pumpers, with the MDI, both in the U.S. and globally and internationally.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So the real focus there becomes, okay, how do we focus now on the pumper segment and the connectivity over there?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And like I said, I think we'll do that with a little bit of catch-up with Libre, too, in terms of what is currently offered in the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But then to leapfrog that, I think the combined sensor, glucose-ketone sensor, is ultimately the way we'll play.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we'll see what pump company is going to want to line up to be first on that connectivity if and once we get that approval, because again, I continue to hear from KOL the importance of that product for the pumper segment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, the second part is the basal expansion and, you know, like I said, you can look at the basal population globally, assume a certain penetration rate globally, a certain utilization rate, and that adds a significant amount of growth to that number.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then the third piece of that is really expanding Libre beyond just diabetes and looking at the Lingo platform.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So the adding up and the execution of those strategies are what ultimately gives us confidence that we can get there and we can sustain that 15% growth rate over the next kind of five years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Regarding questions on pumps, listen, I think that it's an important segment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's one that benefits quite significantly from a combined system.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We're now focusing more aggressively on that as it relates to an all-in-one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think the market has spoken in terms of the pump is one choice.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: They want to be able to choose what is the best sensor pump combination.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think right now my view on that is the consumers have spoken, the market has spoken, the regulators have spoken. interchangeability, and I think that our focus will be on providing the best sensor for the pump systems that are out there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that's, I think I covered your Libre questions, I think you had a question on Navitore.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Listen, we're excited about this.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's a large market, it's a large segment here in the US, it's about $3 billion.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Our label is about 50% of the market because we're only approved right now for the high-risk patients.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But it's got a strong clinical profile.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I mean, we'll be sharing data at CRT specifically to this, but I mean, we've already released some data on it last year comparing it to other valve systems.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think that we've been very intentional about wanting to enter this market and to do it in a way that is sustainable.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Expectations?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I mean, I've talked a little bit about this.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: There's obviously two pretty well-entrenched players in the U.S. market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Do I think that we can be a leader in three, four, five years?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think that might be difficult, but I think that we can come into this market and offer another choice, another opportunity that provides additional benefits or differentiated benefits versus other systems that allow us to pick up share.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: If I look at where we are in Europe, we launched this in Europe, and we have high single-digit share in Europe.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we're not in all centers, we're in about half of the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In the centers that we are implanted and available, our share is in the mid-teens.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So you put that together, we're a high single, but where we're competing, we're in the mid-team.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think this will be a ramp.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think we've got the sales force in place.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We wanna roll this out in a way that allows us to be sustainable in that strategy of being able to be a double-digit share gainer over the next couple of years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Appreciate it, thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: One moment for our next question, please.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And our next question will come from Joanne Wunsch from Citibank, your line is open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Good morning, and thank you for taking the questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: I have two.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: The first one has to do with nutrition and if you could outline where the company is in terms of the recovery and when do you think it'll return to growth?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: And then the second question has to do with use of cash.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: What are your thoughts on it and where you are on share repurchases.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Sure.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Well, on nutrition, as I said in the opening statements, production at Sturgis is up and running.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The team is working around the clock, nonstop, very hard.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Number one focus here, as I said, was to serve the customers, get product back on shelves.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We started with WIC.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The inventory levels on our WIC contracts are very good as we entered into Q4.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we then started to focus on our non-WIC brands.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And that's progressed pretty well in the fourth quarter.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And as we go into this year, looking very good.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I would say, if you look at our growth rate, obviously, you've got this year-over-year comp.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You're going to see the growth already in Q1, Joanne, because we were impacted last year in February.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But I guess the right way to look at this is, OK, strip away the comp.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Strip away this year-over-year effect of coming back on the market, et cetera.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I expect our overall nutrition business to be growing at that pre-pandemic level, between 4% and 6%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Our market shares in WIC have largely recovered.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we're seeing a nice cadence of recovery in the non-WIC share here in the US.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think you'll start to see that growth rate already on the print in Q1, obviously in Q2 and Q3.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But the important thing here is we're looking at our share.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And the share recovery is very much in line with our forecast that we've set for the full year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'd like to see our market share get back to pre-pandemic levels by the end of the year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then, sorry, what was your other question?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Use of cash and where would you stand on share repurchases?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Sure.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03

transcript.sentence: Well, use of cash, you know, talked about this, we've taken this balanced approach.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'd say if I were to kind of rank it in terms of use of cash, we're committed to growing a dividend, a strong and growing dividend.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that's probably number one, use of cash.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We announced that increase of about 9% in our dividend last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that I'll say is priority number one.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Number two is obviously ensuring that all of these new products that we've got launching are appropriately resourced in terms of manufacturing and a lot of our CapEx investments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: On the buybacks, we did throughout the first nine months of last year, we had about 3 billion of buybacks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I'd say we probably did a little bit of catch-up there, Joanne, in terms of catching up to some of the dilution as we were focusing on getting our leverage down post-acquisitions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So we did a little bit of catch-up there, and I'd say in terms of buybacks going forward, we'll be contemplating them, and they'll be largely focused on offsetting any kind of dilution that we have this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'd say the other kind of key use here for us this year is going to be debt.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We have some debt towers coming up, and we're not going to be renegotiating those, just given interest rates.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We want to move those off, so that's probably where you see the use of cash.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: On the M&A side, which I know is always a question, so I'll preempt anybody over there who's got that on their list, I've talked about it on several calls, we're interested, we're actively assessing the opportunities, whether it's tucking on up.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Clearly the valuations here have come down somewhat.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think they need to stabilize a little bit, but we've cast a pretty wide net.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Diagnostics devices are the areas where we have most interest.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And again, if it's financially makes sense for our shareholders and it fits strategically, then we've got that strategic flexibility in our balance sheet to do that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we're gonna be looking at businesses where we can bring value.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Whether we can accelerate sales, whether we can enhance an R&D program or enhance its probability of success.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: A growth area that we can build and have a path to building a position or even if it's just to augment our own existing pipeline.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think when we've taken that approach, our track record shows that when we've taken that approach, it's largely been very successful for our shareholders.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: One moment for our next question, please.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And our next question will come from Vijay Kumar from Evercore ISI.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Your line is open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Hey guys, thanks for taking my question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Good morning to you, Robert.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Maybe my first question on your organic growth assumptions here, I think I heard eight plus is a reasonable number for our 23, what is that assuming for any impact from China supply chain, any VBP impact, if you could just give us some assumptions around those macro factors that would be helpful.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: Well, I'll let Bob talk a little bit about some of the, you know, potentially other macro factors.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: But the ones you've just mentioned here, I mean, China, you know, it's an important market for us, Vijay.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: It's an important growth market and it's good that it's moved to a more, you know, kind of reopening play.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: I think that has not only a big impact for us in China where we've got a strong position.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I mean, we're not overly reliant.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'd say it's about less than 5% of our total sales, but nonetheless, it's an important kind of growth market for us, and I think that reopening in China is gonna have a real positive spillover effect in other areas of the world, and I would say, predominantly in Asia, Southeast Asia, where we've got strong positions in our EPD and in our nutrition business and in some device areas too, So I think the overall opening of China is good.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Like Bob said, there's gonna be some choppiness in the first quarter because we're seeing a lot of cases, hospitalizations, et cetera.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But I think as that moves, starts to move down, I think we'll see a pretty strong rebound in our growth prospects over there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So the VVP that you mentioned, yeah, I mean, that does have an impact. it's more restricted for 2023 in our electrophysiology business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So we'll feel a little bit of an impact there, but I think that the market opens up for us because of the strategy we took on the VVP side.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think it's a net, net it's gonna be positive for us in the longterm here, medium longterm in terms of that being an opportunity for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We've seen this Vijay, I mean, this happened to us, this happened in the market with Stents in 2019, in our vascular business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: That business is back to what I would call pre-VVP levels, you know, this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, there's an impact.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In that case, we didn't necessarily, you know, win some of the contracts.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In the case of EP, we did win the contract, so, or a portion of the contract.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, I'd say macro, yeah, we've got some of these headwinds we've talked about.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: FX, I think Bob's already talked about it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Inflation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But all those seem to be, you know, easing off a little bit.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And the recovery of the procedures and the pipeline and the product launches is a key growth driver for us.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Understood.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Then, Bob, I want to hear on that gross margin here at 56%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: That's a step down year on year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, when I look at pre-pandemic, you know, you guys were at 59%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Is there a simple bridge, Bob, on how much of this has been inflation?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, you did spoke about hedging impact.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Is that all hitting your gross margin line?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And why shouldn't inflationary pressures improve?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And when can we start seeing gross mortgages creep back up to pre-pandemic levels?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Yeah.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, you know, as I said in my opening remarks, around 56% for the year, that's a modest step up kind of from where we exited last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: As you would expect, Vijay, in this environment, there's a lot of different dynamics that multinationals are facing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We've got some headwinds.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We've talked about those, inflationary impact, how that flows through, including the inventory we built last year that will be sold this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We talked about currency where we're not going to see a repeat of those hedging gains that we had in 22.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: So that's a bit of a headwind there.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: On the positive side, I'd say the recovery we're forecasting in the US infant nutrition business will contribute positively.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: And as that recovery occurs over the course of the year, that will have a more positive impact.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcript.sentence: We also have gross margin improvement programs across all of our businesses that, you know, will help to offset some of those headwinds.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01

transcript.sentence: And we're taking price where we can, I'd say, in our more consumer-facing businesses.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And then finally, I'd say, just to kind of from a mixed standpoint, as we continue to see an acceleration in our medical device business with some of these new product launches, those are at higher gross margins than the overall company, and that will positively contribute to our gross margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: If you, to your question about where we were pre-pandemic and what we're guiding to this year, I'd say the biggest impact on a cumulative basis has really been inflation.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: And that's really, I'd say, the big difference here in terms of where we're guiding right now and where we were pre-pandemic.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: But as we continue to see an acceleration from a mixed standpoint and continue to work at some of our costs, we'd expect over time to see that gross margin continue to improve.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Understood.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Thank you, guys.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: One moment for our next question, please.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: And our next question will come from Travis Steed from Bank of America.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Your line is open.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: Hi.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Good morning.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Thanks for taking the questions.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Just a follow-up to Vijay's question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: On the inflation piece, is that still a billion dollars baked into the 440 guidance?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: So to make sure I understand what's baked in on the gross margin line and then anything to call out on On the 2023 operating margin expansion and the moving parts to get the the op margin expansion there
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_06

transcript.sentence: It looks like 22% is kind of what's implied by the guide Yeah, so, you know on the gross on the operating margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_10

transcript.sentence: Yeah, we're around 22% kind of where we were Pre-pandemic, you know, we're getting a high, you know, the high single-digit growth on the top line kind of in the you know excluding the COVID testing.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We're getting leverage down to the P&L, which Robert talked about, where we were able to forward invest over the last couple of years.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We're going to get leverage in the expense area.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And that gets you to about around 22% off margin.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: In terms of inflation, we are going to see a carryover impact from last year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Still pretty meaningful.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But we've been able to mitigate a good portion of that through both our gross margin improvement programs that we have across our businesses, as well as taking some price where we can.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Okay, that's helpful.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I have a couple of product questions on EP.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think you mentioned the new EP catheter mapping system.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I don't know if that was new, maybe I missed that in the past.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'm curious how you're thinking about pulse validation and the impact on your EP business.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then the other product question was on Libre.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The vitamin C, is that on Libre 2 or Libre 3?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I want to understand the pathway to get vitamin C on Libre III and the timing there?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Sure, on the Libre III, VIT-C, I mean, it's gonna start off with Libre II, so we wanna get that done first, and then we'll progress on to Libre III.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So focus right now is on Libre II, and then we'll move to Libre III.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: On your question on EP, I mean, I think the new catheter that we've launched in Japan and started to launch in Europe towards the end of last year is our PactiFlex, which is really using contact force together with the flexible tip that we had in our flex catheters.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So the feedback we've gotten on that is really, really positive.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think the combination here of, you know, our enhanced new mapping system together with our market-leading mapping catheter and HDGrid, and now bringing PactiFlex, that combination is very powerful.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Regarding PFA, it's definitely an area of interest.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We've been investing in it.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We actually had two internal programs, had a bake-off and saw the one that we felt stronger about.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Taking some of the learnings that we're seeing from the current on-market products, and there's obviously some trialing that's ongoing right now, But I would say it's a growth opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00

transcript.sentence: It's an interesting area.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: I think it's still too early to say in terms of will the market move completely over to this technology or not.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: I think it's important to have it, and hence why we're investing in our program and incorporating into our R&D program all of a sudden the deficiencies that we've heard from some of the current on-market products are the ones that are being put in development right now.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_11

transcript.sentence: So important area, important investment area for us in EP, definitely benefited from kind of the investments that we made during COVID.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I think it's an important product to have.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's ability to convert, I think it'll convert a portion of the market.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: My sense is Cryo is probably the first one, but how much of Cryo, still up to see, but definitely an interesting area for investment.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Great.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thank you.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And our last question will come from Matt Miksic from Barclays.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Hey, thanks for fitting me in.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I figured maybe just if we could wrap it up with an update on a couple of the pipeline products, the five products, Robert, that you've highlighted in the past, Amulet and CardioMem, maybe if you could just talk a little bit about where you are with these launches in terms of size, scale, momentum, and maybe what kinds of catalysts we can look for, metrics we can see for these two products this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Thanks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Sure.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Well, I mean, I think those five products that I discussed on the last call, We talked about them exiting at an annual run rate of 500.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: They actually exited at a run rate of 550, and they grew around 100%.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I expect those five products to kind of have maybe not 100%, but pretty high growth rate in this year.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Regarding Amulet, listen, I think, like I said, That's a great space.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We've been rolling out the product last year, building the sales force.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Key focus here is obviously ensuring good implanting technique with the physicians.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We're in about 225 accounts right now.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I expect that in terms of growth catalysts, getting more share of those existing accounts as the physicians become more and more accustomed using our product and see the benefits of using our product versus other systems.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think that'll be a growth catalyst.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And then expanding.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We do want to start to expand more as our sales force has increased, the competency of our sales team has increased, and our clinical team has increased, we feel more confident now to be able to kind of expand to more accounts, and that's what we'll be focused on.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Another key catalyst of growth here is obviously the trial that we've been investing in in catalysts, which is to compare AMULET to novel oral anticoagulant.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So that's another opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's not one in 2023, but continuing that enrollment in that trial is an important driver for kind of the long-term growth strategy here of AMULET.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: CardioMEDS has done very good.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We saw an indication expansion last year in the U.S., seen a nice step up in sales.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think it's a great long-term opportunity.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think it's part of those five products that are driving a lot of growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And I'd say probably the next kind of big area, I mean, we've been investing in Salesforce and rolling this out.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: Next big area here is working on that NCD.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think that will remove some of the, maybe some regional hang-ups in terms of reimbursement.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So the NCD is something that we're gonna be working on this year with the data that we've collected as part of all of our trials.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So I think they look very strong as part of that group of five products.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I'd like to close up the call here, just a few a few remarks.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The operating environment still remains challenging, right?
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: But it's not as challenging as we saw back in Q3 of 2022 in October.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: There are definitely signs here of stability.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: There are signs of improvement, whether it's in the macroeconomic side or whether it's specifically in the segments that we are competing in.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And Abbott's well-positioned. well-positioned to both capitalize on this improving environment or to navigate if there's any unforeseen volatility over here.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: That's what our portfolio has been built for.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: That's what our balance sheet is set up for.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: It's set up for these kind of situations, these kind of scenarios.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We always knew that pandemic-level testing was not a base case.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We knew that eventually This would move down to an endemic-like testing, and we're, you know, our view here is that in 2023, we'll start this process of moving to that, and so as a result of that, we did do this forward investing into our growth areas, whether it's devices, diagnostics, certain areas in EPD or nutrition, and that's allowed us to grow at the pre-pandemic level, high single-digit top-tier growth without having to make the, you know, op-ex investment that you would expect to be able to sustain that growth.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So we're getting that flow-through on the P&L and that leverage on our investments.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I do recognize the cost pressures.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: The company recognized those cost pressures.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: We talked about this now, you know, to Vijay's question.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: You know, we're going to be working relentlessly on getting our gross margin, you know, back to that pre-pandemic level and it's a combination of, you know, working at our cost profiles and our GMI programs, but also as we accelerate the growth in our device business, that mixed shift contributes to that.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So, and finally, our balance sheet is strong and provides us the strategic flexibility we need to navigate.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: And we take this balanced approach where we can provide returns to our shareholders while at the same time investing for the long term.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: So thank you for being on the call overall.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think Abbott is very well positioned as we kind of exit this kind of pandemic state and move into more of an endemic state.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07

transcript.sentence: I think we're well positioned and now it's all about execution.
transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_07
